title: What would Leonardo da Vinci be doing if born in today's world? - Quora

response.answer_text: He’s a problem solver par excellence so he would be doing that in many fields. He would not be an artist first. Even though he brought the sensibility of an artist as well as a designer to all he did. I could see him studying physics because the underlying nature of things consumed him. He had the urge & capacity to stare at a small waterfall, see & sketch exactly what happened to the water when it landed. To anyone else it just disappears into the water it falls into. To Leonardo it became evident it went to all sides & underneath & up again in various patterns, currents & rhythms. Which he sketched to what degree & force it did these things (not all to the same extent he showed). He also wanted to know everything about aerodynamics which he discovered many centuries (at least 4) before the rest of the world, inventing the airplane (in all but the power source, the engine) & an equally correct helicopter. Therefore like many physicists I don’t see him staying in that field, consumed as he was, to work with, design & create powerfully effective things to channel these forces. He was ever mindful of commercial success as well, even if he didn’t let it compromise his passion for Art. When he was looking for work he presented the most ingenious weaponry designs to ingratiate himself with royalty he wished to have hire him. The tank was one such invention he thus presented. He did some remarkable mechanical engineering for the church to raise parts of a stage allied with strategically created smoke to create a magical effect & much else. I could see him doing engineering work for some corporation & eventually going freelance and/or having his own start up. He’d be extremely inventive in channelling some fundamental, scientific principles into work that would manifest in society in the most dramatically, powerful ways. Luck of the draw as to where he would start. Medical devices, nuclear energy, environmental solutions in terms of alternative power sources or maximizing efficiency in current ones, applying quantum physics to computing or elsewhere - he could do it all in terms of the fundamentals & to some meaningful extent, would likely try & then work towards manifesting them in real time. He was one the highest paid artists in the world once offering one of his works he wanted to move at a significant discount to a Duke, who still turned it down because it was still so fabulously expensive. He liked making money & certainly would’ve been a wealthy man today by leveraging his talents in the tech & related world. As for making Art, he’d do that too - on the side (perhaps owning a gallery) & when/if he retired.

Honestly? He'd probably be flipping burgers for a living. The reason I say that is that Da Vinci was infamous during his lifetime as a serial procrastinator. He would often start works and never finish them. In fact, very few of his works were ever finished. The Mona Lisa took him a decade and a half to complete, and some say he was never truly satisfied with it. In 67 years he finished a whopping 15 paintings in total. Many of the "great works" attributed to him, like the Vitruvian Man or his flying machines, are actually nothing but notebook doodles he made in his spare time. Da Vinci was able to survive as an artist because the few works he was able to finish were so spectacular and because artists were very much glorified during the Renaissance. Being a patron to a famous artist was very fashionable then, so patrons were willing to overlook his, well let's not mince words, his laziness. But today artists are nowhere near as venerated, and extreme procrastination is not tolerated.

He was a polymath, highly skilled as a painter, sculptor, architect, musician, mathematician, engineer, inventor, anatomist, geologist, cartographer, botanist, and writer. Today :He would be a genius, billionaire, playboy, philanthropist designing and manufacturing military weapons. He would start one of the most successful rock bands while painting on the side. He would take pictures and write articles for Discover magazine, travel the world looking for weird plants or unusual places man has ever seen. He would start a game company and made the best game every year with his badass engineering, graphics and music skill.

Well, being the illegitimate son of a rich guy in the days of DNA testing, his mother would receive child support. As a boy in the public education system, he'd be more readily diagnosed with the ADHD he probably had. The medication he received would allow him to work more efficiently, completing projects on time and so forth. His insatiable curiosity would be satisfied by public libraries and the internet. All of the above would result in a stellar academic performance that would open every university's doors to him. And whether by scholarships, student loans, or the rich father who might decide he wants the prestige of his son's accomplishments, he'd go to the best of the best, probably majoring in engineering and minoring in fine arts, accomplishing much the same as he did during his actual lifetime. Except probably not as an anatomist.

To be absolutely honest, knowing his reputation to not finish things, it would depend entirely on whether he was born into money or into a working class family. If he had the money then he could get away with living the same type of life he did in the Renaissance. Basically, being a brilliant but somewhat lazy, yet obsessive, perfectionist.  But with no money.... in these days he would have had to struggle his way through to college, being pushed towards something secure. He's probably end up a High School Math teacher slowly working through his many and varied creative pursuits in his spare time.

Thanks for A2A. He would be founder and CEO of "Custom printing of ART on dresses", his art would be compelling to buy "today" as his art was compelling in "his time". His 3D art on dresses would be like living in a 4D world :DHis ideas would make that company more famous than any social networking site in today's life. Note: These "ideas" do not exist now :D A BILLIONAIRE basically I guess :P Example site: Custom T-Shirt Printing Edit: Another thing if he would be in today's world is 2. He would be the founder of "World Space Research Center" similar to NASA but way more advanced in technology, exploration and more.Technologies in Men in Black, Iron Man, Back to the future etc would have been a reality. :D

Leonardo was good at three things that have caught my eye. 1.) Leverage in terms of putting together a staff to implement his designs and 2.) drawing on others work to incorporate into his newer designs. 3.) addressing problems that were waiting for solutions funded by "patrons". I assume that if he were alive today those skills would benefit him greatly. he would go looking for problems to be solved that would give him visibility and would pay him enough to continue his work. Finding those areas today is difficult, but I imagine it was 1500 also.

Let's see.  Da Vinci was an artist and an innovator.  He was a man of great curiosity and intellectual capability.  He made discoveries, and invented, and was rather well-rounded. In today's world, we are usually much more specialized in our endeavors, so I would think da Vinci would gravitate to something very interdisciplinary. Perhaps a professor at a research university, doing something along the lines of engineering, pushing the boundaries.  He would have multiple graduate degrees in disparate fields.

Let us see what he is: Leonardo da Vinci was a polymath: painter, sculptor, architect, musician, mathematician, engineer, inventor, anatomist, geologist, cartographer, botanist, and writer. The crowds may still queue to see his most famous artworks - Money+FameT-shirts may  bear his most famous drawings - Fame+MoneyWe might have bring him to Quora, as he is a good writer - Top Writer on Quora People may speculate about his private life and, particularly about his love affairs/political entry - CelebrityNoble prize for his brilliant research work - TributeCriticism for his Monalisa painting and other unfinished works. (He is a good procrastinator, well suits into this generation) - CriticismThanks for the A2A!

Da Vinci left behind a staggering amount of unfinished works, design sketches for machines that were never built, and so on. The Mona Lisa is technically an unfinished work, he tinkered with it for year after year. In our goal-driven, results-oriented society, he'd probably end up as your crazy uncle who tinkers in his garage and owns twenty patents on things nobody wants to build.

It’s hard to say what would become of someone like da Vinci if he or she were born in today’s world. It was a lot easier to be a “renaissance man” during the renaissance than it would be today. The enormous explosion of scientific and technical knowledge that’s taken place over the past 500 years is breathtaking. It now takes a lifetime of hard study and work to master one tiny branch of science or technology. Da Vinci was the great genius of his time. His intellect and talents would shine in any age. It’s hard to imagine, however, that he’d be able to master the vast scope of contemporary science and technology while also producing great works of art. It’s not clear to me that our times even support the production of “great art”. We may have developed our intellect at the expense of our souls. History will be our judge.

Excellent question! The first thing that came to my mind was ‘Elon Musk’. Both of them are brilliant, but, after a while, I realised that I can’t see other similarities apart from brilliance. Da Vinci was a polymath. He was a scientist, artist, architect, historian etc. But, he rarely ever finished what he started. Honestly, I have no idea what would he be doing if he was born in today’s world. Maybe, with our technology, he would come up with something extraordinary, any field given. Or maybe, just beacuse he ‘rerely ever finished what he started’, he would be like everybody else, a normal human.

He’d be a prominent personality on Quora. Unfortunately, I would have to turn down his marriage proposal, as I am already married. But he would be a well-known character all around the Italian drop zones.

Da Vinci is romanticized as a prolific inventor and genius, yet as many others have commented most of his work was conceptual and unfinished. It was very common for the rich of his era to support artists, it was the thing to do, but not so much today. I suspect Leonardo would have difficulty making a living with his conceptual work as the business world of the 21st century is result oriented. However in today's world wealthy patronage has been replaced to some degree with government assistance, so maybe Da Vinci might live on the dole while he painted and played with conceptual ideas. The good news for Leo is that in today's world he could come out of the closet without any fears of social or financial reprisal.

Nothing remarkable probably. The Swiss historian Jakob Burkhard said that Leonardo Da Vinci was the clearest and most explanatory example of the concept of Man of the Renaissance, precisely because of the multiplicity and complexity of his interests. In today's hyper-technological society, where specialization and fragmentation of the field of study are everything, a man like Leonardo would find it very difficult to adapt. Perhaps he would be a passable theoretical physicist, or a mathematician with a tenure somewhere ... but he would not be a happy and accomplished man as he was in the Renaissance.

he would throw paint randomly on sheets of paper and charge crap load of moneyKidding aside, i think he can invent or draft designs for many futuristic inventions and appliances. Most people only know him as a painter for Mona Lisa. But he was much more than that. He was a pioneer, sculptor, architect, musician, mathematician, engineer, anatomist, geologist and cartographer. Companies would compete to hire his skills and he would win a few prestigious awards.He would be like Ton Stark. rich and powerful and also brilliant minded

DaVinci was talented across a broad range of disciplines. We live in a world of hyper-specialists, where the market favors "deep over broad." My speculation is that he would make a comfortable living toiling in obscurity, because people always need a "jack of all trades," but we don't live in a world that gives much credit to broad-based thinkers. We no longer praise people for being "men of arts, science, and letters."

I think he would forgo university education as it is too restrictive for his taste. So he will not become a scientist inventing things. He could taught himself design or architecture and become world famous designer or architect. Or he'll be in hollywood making movies. (He create popular artworks that makes money. In his day it was paintings and sculpture for rich people. Today it is live action adaptation of marvel comics.)
Many would confuse him with Leonardo Di Caprio.

Thanks for the A2A. Just my opinion, I think probably a venture capitalist, considering most of his life was involved in all sorts of ventures and persuading rulers to fund them. Da Vinci's other talents would probably be incidental bonuses in the modern world. When it comes to getting ventures off the ground, I don't think any modern-day artist, scientist, engineer, etc, could outgun him.

Nothing. He would just be a normal person. Understand that personalities, skills and attributes are defined by nurture, and not nature. Genes only define physical aptitude and properties, rarely intellect and mind. If Leonardo da Vinci was born in today's world, he wouldn't be the Leonardo da Vinci we know.

I think that its likely that if he was alive in today's modern world..he'd be too distracted to do anything worthwhile. With so many options, this master of all trades would be perplexed about what he should focus on.  I think with too many options, problems arise. And I think Vinci would totally relate to that!
